transcripts.text: Russell, in these last three post-seasons, is there a common thread that you've kind of seen carry out through the series?
You said through a series or through each?  Yeah, through each series.
Has there been a common theme that you kind of look back on and say that's something that needs to be fixed?
No.  Teams are different.  Personnel is different.  The guys we play, a lot of different combinations of the reasons why we lost.
Also, in this particular series, in this season, what do you think you guys need to do better coming back next season?
We look at it, reevaluate, get some time to kind of go back to the drawing board and see how we can be better.  One of the big changes this season was adding Jeremy Grant to the starting lineup.
Just looking back, how do you feel that worked out for you guys?
Great.  Jeremy became a better player.  Approved all year long.  Very consistent at what he was doing.  I'm proud of the things he was able to do, especially coming to this year.
Russell, what's your sense of how Paul George's shoulder injury affected the ultimate destiny?

I'm not sure.  When Paul gets here, you can kind of ask him about that.  But Paul did an amazing job all year long and was consistent.  And obviously, I'm our best player all year.  And he did that for us, and he did his part.  Where do you feel like?  you and PG together took a step together this year and progressed as just playing football?  I thought we did a good job of playing off each other, figuring out what is best for each of us.  And I think, like I said before, ultimately the most important part is off the floor, creating a friendship and a brotherhood.  The basketball stuff will take care of itself, but you only can play basketball for so many years.  And after that, friendships and the things you create while you're playing is most important.
Russell Billy into an offseason with a sense of what you want to work on personally or does that come over time?
Come over time, figure it out.

Russell Billy talked about how there was a respect and communication between you all that he liked this season and the seasons before.  What have you thought about the relationship between you and Billy over these last four years?

It's been good.  You know, me personally never had a problem with Coach Donovan, and we always been straightforward with each other and always had a good communication of, you know, respect for each other's jobs and respect for how hard we both work at what we want best for this team.  So it's been good.  Back to your season, how much, if at all, did missing training camp affect getting into the rhythm of things and all that?  I don't know.  It doesn't matter.  It doesn't matter.  I don't practice doing training camp anyway.

Russ, during the playoff series, you know, you would say that most players are dealing with some level of injury throughout it, but were you dealing with anything through that series?  Is it something that you'd have to address in the offseason?
It was all right.
What's the process that you go through when you're struggling shooting from a particular area, but teams are giving you that area to shoot from?
There's no process.  Shoot it.  That's it.
You didn't shoot as well as you've done in the past.  In the playoffs, you were really good at it.  Did you just get in the rhythm?
No, just changed some stuff up.
Anything you can tell us?  I mean, what you changed up?
No.

Heading into the season, you guys talked about wanting to play with more pace.  I think you finished sixth in pace.  Defense had fallen off last year without Andre.  I think you guys finished fifth.  Were there some things that happened, some things that you guys tried to cultivate throughout the year to make those things possible?

Definitely.  I mean, that's kind of what we stood on personally, just trying to figure out what's best for our team, our personnel.  You got to kind of see what defense you're able to play with the guys you have, the size, the length, the guys that are available to make your team the best it can be defensively, and that's what we try to do.

We've got about five, six minutes.  Nobody's brought up triple-double.  Three straight years doing that.  Have you made that sort of passe where it's not a big deal anymore because you're able to do it so much?
I just play, man.  That's it.  If it's passe, so be it.  It's okay.  Let somebody else do it.  I try to.  It's all right.
What will your offseason be like?  I mean, in terms of just, will you be like the others?
I mean, in terms of the work you do?  Last offseason, I had one kid.  This year, I have three.  I don't know.
It won't be the same.  Do you kind of take a step back?  You're 11 years into the league.  Do you do the same things?  Do you kind of give your body a break?
I do not do the same thing.  I will not.
Russell, you mentioned the children, not to make an excuse or anything, but does that have an effect on your preparation for the season?
What?
Like, you having children, does that have an effect on preparation for a season and just how you've gone about looking ready for it?

No, no.  Family is the most important thing to me.  Always have, always will be.  Like I said, basketball is a short period of your life.  You only get to play for whether it's 20 years or 10 years, two, seven, eight, whatever it is.  But you have a life to live.  You have kids.  You have me personally.  I have other things that's more important to worry about.  It doesn't change.  To me, it's all intact.  My family, my preparation, we're all on the same page.  But I do know what's priority.
Do you plan to play for Team USA this summer?

Do I plan to play?  Am I on the list?  We'll see then.  I'll make a decision when that comes about.  I don't know if you've thought about it.  No, I haven't.  I haven't yet.  I think I'm gonna make sure I'm on a list.  that probably took me off.  You gotta see, maybe.  Maybe it took me off.

I know during the season, you mentioned that you have a talent for not paying attention to the noise or the talk around you.  But what have these past few days been like in terms of that coming off the series and the way that y'all finished?
What about it?
Just people talking about the Lillard talk, the back and forth in the series.

It doesn't change much, man, honestly.  Yeah.  If you want to determine my career and what I've done over two, three games, you go ahead.  That'll mean to me.  It doesn't.  I'm gonna wake up.  Like I told you before, three beautiful kids.  I'm gonna wake up, smile, be happy, enjoy my life.  Doesn't change anything about me.  Talk about if I play bad or who's better, who's not.  I know who I am as a person, and that's the biggest thing I can say about myself.  I know who I am.  I know what I'm able to do.  I know my capabilities.  I know what I've done.  I know what I can and can't do.  So I'm okay with that.  I'm okay with who I am.  I'll just be blessed to wake up every day and enjoy my life.  So to talk about, I don't even know what you're talking about, but whatever that is, you guys can keep talking about it, and I'm going to keep living my life.
What can your team do to improve individually and also as a unit?
Wait, hold on.
How can you all improve as a unit?

You know, there's different ways that we can improve as a team.  Me personally, there's a lot of different ways.  Obviously, this year I definitely could have played better.  But, you know, there's room for improvement every year.  And I always find a way to be able to come back better at something and figure out what's better for our team and what's best for our team at the time.

Go ahead, Brett.  The game has changed a lot even since you came into it.  And I wonder if there's any, do you feel like there needs to be any more emphasis on you as a jump shooter, as a three-point shooter?  Do you need to get better at that?

Jump shooter or three-point shooter?  Three-point shooter.  There can be emphasis.  I mean, you guys can talk about it, but I'll just continue doing what I'm doing and obviously finding ways to pick and shoot better ones.  But that's up to me.  But that's that.
Other than jump shooting, what are some other specific areas about your great game that you want to improve coming into next year?

Everything.  I always tell you that because I know I can do everything at a high level.  So I always find ways to make sure that I'm able to do that.  And that's one thing about me.  It's that, and I think a lot of times, whether it's you guys or whoever it is, people across the world, when you do so much, you got so much you're doing throughout a game, whether it's defending, rebounding, passing.  Used to be conversations of I was a ball hog, but now... Now I lead the league in assists for the past three years or whatever it is.  That's getting squashed out.  So now the conversation is about shooting.  Next year, I'm going to become a better shooter.  After that, it'd be probably my left foot is bigger than my right one.  Who knows?  to me that's the.  that's why i know that when you do so much with the game you got so much impact on the game.  uh i expect a lot out of myself.  uh put a lot of pressure on myself to become uh a very, very great player because I know that I'm able to do so much throughout the game to impact the game, impact winning.  So that's why, back to your point, I don't really care what people say, what they think about me, because it doesn't really matter.  I know what I'm able to do and know what I'm able to do at a high level every night, and nobody else can do what I can do on a night-and-night-out basis.  And I truly believe that if they could, I'm pretty sure they would.  But I know for a fact that nobody can.  Do you think it's kind of strange that you get criticized as much as you do, given how much success you've had?  No, I don't, man.  When you do so much at a high level, a lot of haters come.  That's how life is, man.  That's life, man, when you... When you do so much, people gonna try to pull and take away and try to take that away from you.  But nobody can take away from you.  I've been blessed.  I stay prayful, stay thankful to be able to do what I'm able to do.  And nobody can never take that away from me, regardless of what it is, how many stories are written, how many stats are put up, how many numbers are put up.  It doesn't matter.  I take too much pride, time, effort to be able to go out and compete and play hard every night.  My body on the line can't take it away from me.  I will never let anybody take it away.  How many years you'll ask me?  every year I take the same masters because I truly believe it and doesn't change the fact of anything.
How was your first year playing with Dennis?

Let's talk about that.  It's good.  You know, Dennis did a good job of figuring out, obviously, which best way he can kind of fit and what's the best way for him to be successful.  I think it was a learning process for all of us, and I think he did a good job of trying to figure it out as well as everybody else.  Chris, when you look at your developments into rookie season, what are you most proud of?  My development as a leader.  As a leader, I think leadership is one thing that
I've

– taking pride in and trying to figure out the best way to better lead guys into a position to where I feel like they're most comfortable with their games and still in confidence in them, finding ways to make other guys better.  That's my whole thing.  And I feel like I've done a good job of that each year of making someone or people around me better players.  Even if people leave, you know, they still become better players.  So I feel like I try to make people better players as much as I can.
Russ, is there a certain type of teammate that you want to work out with in the summer?

I work out with all my teammates, not one particular.  I'll stay in touch with all my guys and communicate with them and create a relationship like I've done before.  Nothing changes for me with that, and I'll do the same thing.
You all had a career year in a lot of ways, second in the league in scoring.

What did you see from them in particular?  that you had improved the most?  He was aggressive.  He came out with a mindset of he wanted to be the best, and he showed that.  He did a good job of staying consistent and was aggressive, scoring, defending at a high rate, doing what we needed for him to do for our team to be successful, and he did that.
Anybody else?  Russ, you've lost a lot since you've been here.  Does it drive you?

Does it bother you to have gone out the first round these three years?  Bother?  Yes.  Drive, I guess, but I don't really need nothing to drive me to be who I want to be or to be where I want to be.  Obviously, me personally, I want to be able to become the best where I can be.  And obviously win the championship.  Yeah, obviously I wouldn't want to be sitting here talking to you guys at the end of the season.  But unfortunately, that's what happened.  And with that, you got to go to the drawing board.  And me personally, I always look at myself for how I can be better, whether it's playing a better series, preparing better for the series.  Preparing for the season.  Obviously, when you lose a series, everybody looks at the series and say, this is the reason why you lost.  But that's not ultimately what happens throughout a year.  There's a different things that happen to you to a team that can either you either you got it, you're clicking or you're not.  So there's a combination of a lot of things.  But me personally, I just know that moving and going into next year, I'm going to just do what I need to do to make sure that I'm staying consistent at what I do and being better.
Any one thing you can put on the line down the stretch?  You guys went from three to six.  You weren't playing well.  Do you think you can put on why that happened?

No, I can't.  I can't.  I don't know why that happened.  Maybe we lost games or the team won games.  I don't really know what happens.  I mean, at the end of the year, we won six straight games.  But it was too late.  Other teams were already winning, and they were winning at the same time.  we were winning.  So you can't really control that.  You can only control what you can control.  And that's it.  That's all.  That's what I believe in, in anything.  You control what's going on in this building.  I can control that.  I control myself.  I control the way we come out to play.  That's it.  Everything else is really out of my control, out of my hands.  Thank you, Russell.  Thank you.
